The Governor announced his Executive Order on June 7, extending the deadline for school districts to receive school budget ballots. To be counted, school budget absentee ballots can be accepted by hand delivery through 5 p.m. on June 9, or received by mail by 5 p.m. on June 16. The ballot box located in the administration building entry way must be removed at 5 p.m. on June 9 and no additional ballots may be distributed at that point.

Please remember to put your completed ballot inside the absentee ballot envelope. Sign and date the front of the absentee ballot envelope AND print your name, address and town on the back. BOTH SIDES MUST BE COMPLETED TO BE VALID. Place the sealed absentee ballot envelope in the postage paid return envelope and return. If you have questions please contact the District Clerk at 637-1939 or District.Clerk@bcs1.org.

One Hill School team holds a “pajama social” read aloud twice a week and weekly craft nights with students and parents.

The teacher, Christopher Albrecht, begins the pajama social to build curiosity by sharing objects and inviting students to share ideas about what they have been doing before reading the story for the night. The first craft the team made was bird feeders using toilet paper rolls, bird seed and peanut butter. A clip of students working on one of their crafts can be viewed below.

Mr. Albrecht says he began the read alouds and craft nights because he believes the social emotional learning is just as important as the cognitive learning students get through school.

For more on this and other BCSD "stories to inspire," visit our website, here: http://bcs1.ss14.sharpschool.com/news/what_s_new/bcsd_covid-19/b_c_s_d_-_stories_to_inspire

The teacher, Christopher Albrecht, begins the pajama social to build curiosity by sharing objects and inviting students to share ideas about what they have been doing before reading the story for the night. The first craft the team made was bird feeders using toilet paper rolls, bird seed and peanut butter. A clip of students working on one of their crafts can be viewed below.

Mr. Albrecht says he began the read alouds and craft nights because he believes the social emotional learning is just as important as the cognitive learning students get through school.

For more on this and other BCSD "stories to inspire," visit our website, here: http://bcs1.ss14.sharpschool.com/news/what_s_new/bcsd_covid-19/b_c_s_d_-_stories_to_inspire
